turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm thinking of joining this hackathon, but I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed. I've never done one before. Any advice?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Hi! Absolutely! Hackathons can be daunting at first. To start, what's the theme of the hackathon? Knowing that will help me tailor advice to your specific situation.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: It's focused on building solutions for sustainable living. I'm not sure what skills are most useful for that, or even where to begin with an idea.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, sustainable living is broad, but great! Think about specific problems within that area. For example, waste reduction, energy efficiency, or promoting sustainable transportation. Skills-wise, coding is often helpful, but not always necessary. Design thinking, project management, and communication are also crucial. Do you have any particular skills you want to leverage?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hmm, I'm decent at Python and have some experience with web development. But how do you even come up with a good idea that's feasible in just a weekend? That's the part that really gets me.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Brainstorming is key! Try thinking about everyday problems you face related to sustainability. Even better, talk to people who work in sustainability. See if you can identify a pain point they experience that you can address with your skills. For a weekend hackathon, aim for a *minimum viable product (MVP)* – a basic, functional solution, not a perfect polished one.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, MVP makes sense. But how do I ensure my idea is *actually* innovative and not just a rehash of something that already exists? I don't want to waste time on something pointless. This whole process is a little scary to be honest.
